item.title: Omar's Programming with JavaScript --Basics
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

var month ="March"; document.write(“School starts in” + Month);

OR

month = “March”;
document.write(“School starts in” + Month);

There aren’t the same thing. If you leave off the var statement, you’re putting a new variable in global scope (window). This behaviour is almost never wanted and you should avoid it at all costs. You should really only have one global variable in your program where you define everything under but even that is unnecessary if you use an IIFE.
Var ArrayName= new Array(size);

ArrayName[index]= value;
ArrayName[index2]=value 2 ;

You shouldn’t use the array constructor because it’s slower, more confusing, more verbose and pretty useless. When you use the constructor (new Array(size)), all you’re doing is padding the array with undefined. The same is done if you use square bracket notation and change the length property.

item.description:
@owner5 wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:7, topic:492278”][quote author=owner5 link=topic=610509.msg4234914#msg4234914 date=1361503469]

“No software needed”
Ok I guess a web browser isn’t software

A web browser is used to DISPLAY what you coded. It isn’t used to code…
[/quote]The web browser isn’t an IDE but it does have a core to run the code itself. Chrome with V8, Firefox with Spidermonkey, etc.

In your code you’re using document.write a lot in your examples. Consider using console.log instead, it makes more sense.

MDN Web Docs

Console.log()

Outputs a message to the Web Console.

document.wrong. Please use something more modern and less prone to doing confusing things. This function tries to write to the current document. If the document has already been processed, the document will be replaced with a blank one with your argument. If you don’t want that, use the proper DOM methods instead.

[quote=owner5]
<!- - -Hide below from Non=JavaScript browsers[/quote]Totally unnecessary and invalid. If you’re using HTML5, which you should, only the tag (in lowecase) is necessary. You haven’t needed to use HTML comments since early versions of Netscape and the language attribute has been deprecated for a while.

[quote=owner5]Java vs. JavaScript[/quote]What’s the point in a comparison like this? Java isn’t related to Javascript in the slightest besides the name.

In your variable types you’re missing undefined. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/undefined

[quote=owner5]• The first character must be a letter or an underscore[/quote]Also not true. See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1661197/valid-characters-for-javascript-variable-names

[quote=owner5]var Month =”March”;[/quote]Bad naming convention. In Javascript, the only thing that should have a capital as the first letter are constructors.

justaguy:

Back then, I’m sure this would have been debatable but with Javascript accomplishments on the server (nodejs, Socket.IO, etc.), this is no longer true.[/quote]Even in 2011, node.js was still around, just not as popular. It started in 2009.

I’ve fixed most of what you pointed out. However, I will keep document.write. It still works when i want to display text, and i see nothing wrong with using it for that.
There might be someone who is a complete beginner, and does not know that Java Script and Java are two completely different things.

@owner5 wrote:

I thought i would share some of my knowledge on Javascript with all of you guys. I’ve had a Moparscape account for 6 years and only have 32 posts, which is pretty sad. So here it is…

Note: i created this back in 2011-2012. This is the first time i’m sharing it with anyone.

[size=18pt][font=arial]PROGRAMMING WITH JAVA SCRIPT [/font][/size]

[size=4]CHAPTER 1[/size]
[size=12pt]Server Side[/size]

[size=1em]• Server side scripts reside on the server (main computer) while client side scripts reside on a user PC[/size]
[size=1em]• Storing all programs on the server allows multiple users simultaneous access but poses potential connection and performance issues.[/size]

Client Side
• While client side scripts are not as powerful and will never fully replace server side scripts, they do offer a convenient alternative for performing some of the simple, low-key tasks locally.

Why JavaScript?
• HTML allows developers to create static web pages, the information and look of the page does not change.

• JavaScript allows you to create pages where content and layout can be modified using special code built into the page.

[size=14pt]Java vs. JavaScript
[/size]

I included this for people who have no knowledge of Java or Javascript and would like to know the difference.
Java
• Code is powerful but complex
• A special app (JDK) required
• Programs must be saved and compiles separately
• Used for complex tasks

JavaScript
• Code is easy to learn and to use
• No additional software is needed
• Code can be added directly anywhere in the HTML text editor
• Used for quick, simple tasks

[size=14pt]Code Example[/size]

<script>
document.write(“Today is 12/20/2011 <BR>”)
document.write(“Only 10 days until the New Year!”)
</script>

[size=14pt]Variables[/size]
• A Variable is a verbal representation of information that can be substituted for information.
• Before you can use a variable can be used in the code it has to be created using a variable declaration.

Variable Types

• Numeric variables- any number in standard or scientific notification
• String Variables – text (Must be in quotes)
• Boolean variables- TRUE/FALSE. Used when you want the program to act depending on condition
• Null Variables- a variable without an assigned value.

[size=14pt]Naming Rules[/size]
• The remaining characters must be letters, numbers or underscores
• Names cannot contain spaces
• JavaScript code items cannot be used as variable names.

[size=14pt]Variable Example[/size]
[size=14pt]---------------------------------------[/size]
var month =“March”;
document.write(“School starts in” + Month);

OR

month = “March”;
document.write(“School starts in” + Month);

[size=4]---------------------------------------

[/size]Both of the codes above will yield the same result. Which is: School starts in March

[size=4]Expressions and Operators
[/size]• A JavaScript expression is a command that is used for assigning values to defined variables.
• A JavaScript operator is an element that can be used within an expression to perform and action, such as adding or combining multiple elements…
• The most commonly used operator is the equal sign (=) that will assign a value to the preceding variable.
• Another example of an operator is the plus sign (+) used for combining multiple elements.

[size=4]Assignment Operators
[/size]• In JS, values are assigned to variables using assignment operators.
• An example is the equal sign (=)

[size=4]Functions[/size]
• A function is a series of commands that can be executed by your program to calculate a value or perform an action

[size=4]Benefits of Funtions
[/size]• Complex programming tasks can be broken down into simpler steps
• Code does not have to be duplicated within a program
• Code can be reused multiple times by a placing a simple function call anywhere is the program

[size=4]Declaration[/size]
• A function has to be created using a function declaration like the one below

[size=4]---------------------------------------
[/size]Function Name(Function Variables)
{
Function Commands;
}
[size=4]---------------------------------------
[/size]
[size=4]Three major parts of a function:
[/size]
[ul][li]Function Name= identifies each function[/li]
[li]Parameters= Values needed by the function to produce the expected result[/li]
[li]Commands= Actions that will be executed when the function runs.[/li][/ul]
[size=4]Calling a function[/size]

[ul][li][left]Whenever you need to use the function you created you must insert this piece of code:[/left][/li][/ul]
[size=4]---------------------------------------
[/size]FunctionName(Variables);
[size=4]---------------------------------------
[/size](Replace “FuntionName” with the name you created for your function. Replace “Variables” with whatever variables you need to use)

[size=4]End of Chapter 1
[/size]

[size=4]Chapter 2
[/size]

[size=14pt]Arrays[/size]

• In a typical computer program, data cannot be stored without the use of a database such as Access, Oracle, DB2 etc.

• Some of the program data, however, can be stored on a temporary basis by using data structures known as arrays.

• An array is a systematic arrangement of objects, usually is a rows and columns. Like a table./ single column table with a name assigned to it

[size=14pt]Array Example[/size]
[size=14pt]--------------------------------------------[/size]
Var ArrayName= new Array(size);

ArrayName[index]= value;
ArrayName[index2]=value 2 ;

[size=14pt]--------------------------------------------[/size]

• The size is expressed as the number of elements that the array is going to contain.

• You can leave the size blank and have JavaScript automatically increase the array size as new elements are added.

• Index represents the row number
